prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ULASJ1234+0907 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect CO(3-2) in the quasar ULASJ1234+0907 at z=2.503

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe the target using the TDM mode corresponding to 128 channels over a bandwidth of 2000MHz (1875 MHz effective) per spectral window. This is the largest bandwidth available and is used to account for any potential offsets between the H-alpha derived redshift of our quasar (Banerji et al. 2012) and the CO redshift. The velocity resolution is ~100 km/s. The line is contained in a single baseband and the remaining 3 basebands are positioned so as to enable a reliable continuum measurement. Assuming a linewidth of 600 km/s (typical for quasar host and starburst galaxies), we will spectrally resolve the line into ~6x100 km/s channels, which can be binned up to 4x150 km/s channels if necessary. The spectral resolution in the TDM mode is still sufficient to be able to resolve the line if it is narrower than 600 km/s.

As this is a detection experiment for CO, we can make use of the most compact ALMA configuration available. The C36-1 configuration corresponds to angular scales of ~3.5". In this configuration, the CO emission is expected to be spatially unresolved. However the aim of the current proposal is to detect the molecular gas and measure the line luminosity and molecular gas mass. Future observations will then utilise more extended ALMA configurations in order to spatially resolve the molecular gas and look for signatures of AGN triggering and feedback.

In Banerji et al. (2014), we used far infrared/submillimeter dust continuum observations of ULASJ1234+0907 to measure a conservative star formation rate of 2000 M0/yr in the quasar host galaxy. As detailed in the Scientific Justification, we have used the empirical relationship between the infrared dust luminosity and the CO(1-0) line luminosity as well as a conservative assumption regarding the form of the CO excitation ladder (LCO(3-2)/LCO(1-0)=0.8) to infer the CO(3-2) line luminosity for this quasar. This line luminosity is 5.7e10 K km/s pc^2. The corresponding line intensity is 1.8 Jy km/s. We assume a linewidth of 600 km/s, typical for high redshift quasars and starburst galaxies. Therefore the peak line flux is 3 mJy. Our aim is to detect this line at high significance in order to enable a measurement of the CO line luminosity. We also aim to obtain an estimate of the line profile over 4x150 km/s channels in order to measure the linewidth and therefore get a first order estimate of the dynamical mass of the quasar host galaxy.
Our requested RMS of ~0.3 mJy over a 150 km/s channel is designed to detect the CO(3-2) line at a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 and get a measurement of the line profile.
The continuum flux density has been estimated from the best-fit dust spectral energy distribution (SED) presented in Banerji et al. (2014). While our proposed sensitivity is aimed at a line detection and we do not expect to detect the continuum, any upper limits obtained on this dust continuum will nevertheless provide useful constraints on the cold dust mass.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ULASJ2315+0143 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect CO(3-2) in the quasar ULASJ2315 at z=2.560

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe the target using the TDM mode corresponding to 128 channels over a bandwidth of 2000MHz (1875 MHz effective) per spectral window. This is the largest bandwidth available and is used to account for any potential offsets between the H-alpha derived redshift of our quasar (Banerji et al. 2015) and the CO redshift. The velocity resolution is ~100 km/s. The line is contained in a single baseband and the remaining 3 basebands are positioned so as to enable a reliable continuum measurement. Assuming a linewidth of 600 km/s (typical for quasar host and starburst galaxies), we will spectrally resolve the line into ~6x100 km/s channels, which can be binned up to 4x150 km/s channels if necessary. The spectral resolution in the TDM mode is still sufficient to be able to resolve the line if it is narrower than 600 km/s.

As this is a detection experiment for CO, we can make use of the most compact ALMA configuration available. The C36-1 configuration corresponds to angular scales of ~3.5". In this configuration, the CO emission is expected to be spatially unresolved. However the aim of the current proposal is to detect the molecular gas and measure the line luminosity and molecular gas mass. Future observations will then utilise more extended ALMA configurations in order to spatially resolve the molecular gas and look for signatures of AGN triggering and feedback.

In Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2015), we have used H-alpha IFU observations to measure a star formation rate of 1300 M0/yr in the host galaxy of ULASJ2315+0143. As detailed in the Scientific Justification, we convert this star formation rate to an infrared luminosity using the emprical calibration from Kennicutt & Evans (2012). The infrared luminosity is converted to a CO(1-0) line luminosity using the empirical conversion from Carilli & Walter (2013). We then make a conservative assumption regarding the form of the CO excitation ladder (LCO(3-2)/LCO(1-0)=0.8) to infer the CO(3-2) line luminosity for this quasar. This line luminosity is 4.2e10 K km/s pc^2. The corresponding line intensity is 1.2 Jy km/s. We assume a linewidth of 600 km/s, typical for high redshift quasars and starburst galaxies. Therefore the peak line flux is 2 mJy. Our aim is to detect this line at high significance in order to enable a measurement of the CO line luminosity. We also aim to obtain an estimate of the line profile over 4x150 km/s channels in order to measure the linewidth and therefore get a first order estimate of the dynamical mass of the quasar host galaxy.
Our requested RMS of ~0.2 mJy over a 150 km/s channel is designed to detect the CO(3-2) line at a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 and get a measurement of the line profile.
There are currently no constraints on the 3mm continuum flux density in this object and we have simply scaled down the continuum flux density of ULASJ1234+0907 (Banerji et al. 2014) based on the ratio of the star formation rates in the two objects. While our proposed sensitivity is aimed at a line detection and we do not expect to detect the continuum, any upper limits obtained on this dust continuum will nevertheless provide useful constraints on the cold dust mass.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ULASJ0123+1525 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect CO(3-2) in the quasar ULASJ0123+1525 at z=2.629

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe the target using the TDM mode corresponding to 128 channels over a bandwidth of 2000MHz (1875 MHz effective) per spectral window. This is the largest bandwidth available and is used to account for any potential offsets between the H-alpha derived redshift of our quasar (Banerji et al. 2015) and the CO redshift. The velocity resolution is ~100 km/s. The line is contained in a single baseband and the remaining 3 basebands are positioned so as to enable a reliable continuum measurement. Assuming a linewidth of 600 km/s (typical for quasar host and starburst galaxies), we will spectrally resolve the line into ~6x100 km/s channels, which can be binned up to 4x150 km/s channels if necessary. The spectral resolution in the TDM mode is still sufficient to be able to resolve the line if it is narrower than 600 km/s.

As this is a detection experiment for CO, we can make use of the most compact ALMA configuration available. The C36-1 configuration corresponds to angular scales of ~3.5". In this configuration, the CO emission is expected to be spatially unresolved. However the aim of the current proposal is to detect the molecular gas and measure the line luminosity and molecular gas mass. Future observations will then utilise more extended ALMA configurations in order to spatially resolve the molecular gas and look for signatures of AGN triggering and feedback.

In Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2015), we have used H-alpha IFU observations to measure a star formation rate of 1000 M0/yr in the host galaxy of ULASJ0123+1525. As detailed in the Scientific Justification, we convert this star formation rate to an infrared luminosity using the emprical calibration from Kennicutt & Evans (2012). The infrared luminosity is converted to a CO(1-0) line luminosity using the empirical conversion from Carilli & Walter (2013). We then make a conservative assumption regarding the form of the CO excitation ladder (LCO(3-2)/LCO(1-0)=0.8) to infer the CO(3-2) line luminosity for this quasar. This line luminosity is 3.4e10 K km/s pc^2. The corresponding line intensity is 0.97 Jy km/s. We assume a linewidth of 600 km/s, typical for high redshift quasars and starburst galaxies. Therefore the peak line flux is 1.6 mJy. Our aim is to detect this line at high significance in order to enable a measurement of the CO line luminosity. We also aim to obtain an estimate of the line profile over 4x150 km/s channels in order to measure the linewidth and therefore get a first order estimate of the dynamical mass of the quasar host galaxy.
Our requested RMS of ~0.16 mJy over a 150 km/s channel is designed to detect the CO(3-2) line at a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 and get a measurement of the line profile.
There are currently no constraints on the 3mm continuum flux density in this object and we have simply scaled down the continuum flux density of ULASJ1234+0907 (Banerji et al. 2014) based on the ratio of the star formation rates in the two objects. While our proposed sensitivity is aimed at a line detection and we do not expect to detect the continuum, any upper limits obtained on this dust continuum will nevertheless provide useful constraints on the cold dust mass.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: VHSJ2101-5943 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Detect CO(3-2) in the quasar VHSJ2101-5943 at z=2.313

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe the target using the TDM mode corresponding to 128 channels over a bandwidth of 2000MHz (1875 MHz effective) per spectral window. This is the largest bandwidth available and is used to account for any potential offsets between the H-alpha derived redshift of our quasar (Banerji et al. 2015) and the CO redshift. The velocity resolution is ~100 km/s. The line is contained in a single baseband and the remaining 3 basebands are positioned so as to enable a reliable continuum measurement. Assuming a linewidth of 600 km/s (typical for quasar host and starburst galaxies), we will spectrally resolve the line into ~6x100 km/s channels, which can be binned up to 4x150 km/s channels if necessary. The spectral resolution in the TDM mode is still sufficient to be able to resolve the line if it is narrower than 600 km/s.

As this is a detection experiment for CO, we can make use of the most compact ALMA configuration available. The C36-1 configuration corresponds to angular scales of ~3.5". In this configuration, the CO emission is expected to be spatially unresolved. However the aim of the current proposal is to detect the molecular gas and measure the line luminosity and molecular gas mass. Future observations will then utilise more extended ALMA configurations in order to spatially resolve the molecular gas and look for signatures of AGN triggering and feedback.

In Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2015), we have used H-alpha IFU observations to measure a star formation rate of 590 M0/yr in the host galaxy of VHSJ2101-5943. As detailed in the Scientific Justification, we convert this star formation rate to an infrared luminosity using the emprical calibration from Kennicutt & Evans (2012). The infrared luminosity is converted to a CO(1-0) line luminosity using the empirical conversion from Carilli & Walter (2013). We then make a conservative assumption regarding the form of the CO excitation ladder (LCO(3-2)/LCO(1-0)=0.8) to infer the CO(3-2) line luminosity for this quasar. This line luminosity is 2.3e10 K km/s pc^2. The corresponding line intensity is 0.8 Jy km/s. We assume a linewidth of 600 km/s, typical for high redshift quasars and starburst galaxies. Therefore the peak line flux is 1.3 mJy. Our aim is to detect this line at high significance in order to enable a measurement of the CO line luminosity. We also aim to obtain an estimate of the line profile over 4x150 km/s channels in order to measure the linewidth and therefore get a first order estimate of the dynamical mass of the quasar host galaxy.
Our requested RMS of ~0.13 mJy over a 150 km/s channel is designed to detect the CO(3-2) line at a signal-to-noise ratio of 10 and get a measurement of the line profile.
There are currently no constraints on the 3mm continuum flux density in this object and we have simply scaled down the continuum flux density of ULASJ1234+0907 (Banerji et al. 2014) based on the ratio of the star formation rates in the two objects. While our proposed sensitivity is aimed at a line detection and we do not expect to detect the continuum, any upper limits obtained on this dust continuum will nevertheless provide useful constraints on the cold dust mass.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to detect 12CO(3-2) in 4 dust-obscured (Av~2.5), high luminosity (Lbol~1e14 L0), high star formation rate (SFR > 500 M0/yr) quasars at z~2.5 that are caught in a transformative, radiative-feedback dominated phase as they are transitioning from massive starburst galaxies to unobscured quasars. These dust obscured quasars are the highest luminosity quasars currently known at the main epoch of galaxy and supermassive black hole assembly. The proposed CO detection experiment will lead to a five-fold increase in the number of z~2-3 intrinsically luminous, ALMA-accessible quasars where molecular gas has been detected, thus paving the way for future high-resolution observations to look for signatures of AGN triggering and feedback in these systems. Previous searches for molecular gas in high redshift quasars have tended to focus on gravitationally lensed, intrinsically lower luminosity systems or quasars at redshifts above 4. Studying the molecular gas in our high luminosity, highly star-forming quasar hosts will therefore enable new insights into the interplay between star formation and black hole accretion at an epoch when both quantities were at their peak.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
